options.label: B

options.text: To prevent T cell counts from getting low enough for the disease to progress to AIDS.

options.label: C
options.text: To prevent the virus from making a deadly comeback.

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of access to antiretroviral therapy.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Using genetic tools to cut the HIV DNA out of cells' genomes altogether.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It gives hope that a cure is possible and may lead to further research and development.

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: To produce hormones that regulate blood pressure

options.label: D
options.text: To break down proteins and carbohydrates

multiple-choice.question: How many times does the body's eight liters of blood pass through the kidneys each day?
What is the name of the tiny vessels that entwine with nephrons in the kidneys?

options.label: D
options.text: Not specified in the transcript, but the correct answer is arterioles that branch and branch until they form tiny vessels.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the glomerulus in the nephron?

options.label: A
options.text: To reabsorb vitamins and minerals into the bloodstream

options.label: B
options.text: To detect waste products in the blood

options.label: C
options.text: To filter the blood and allow certain ingredients to pass into the tubule

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the waste products that are detected by the nephrons?

options.label: A
options.text: They are reabsorbed into the bloodstream

options.label: B
options.text: They are redirected as urine out of the kidneys and through the ureters

options.label: C
options.text: They are stored in the liver for later removal

options.label: D
options.text: They are broken down by enzymes in the kidneys

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of low water levels in the blood?

options.label: A
options.text: The kidneys release more water into the urine

options.label: B
options.text: The kidneys release some water back into the bloodstream

options.label: C
options.text: The kidneys stop filtering waste products from the blood

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the hormone erythropoietin?

options.label: B
options.text: To increase red blood cell production

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate fluid levels in the body

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if the kidneys were not functioning properly?

options.label: A
options.text: The body would produce more urine

options.label: B
options.text: The body would retain more water

options.label: C
options.text: The buildup of waste would overload the systems and lead to expiration

options.label: D
options.text: The body would regulate its own fluid levels

multiple-choice.question: How many nephrons are present in each kidney?
What is the result of the kidneys controlling water levels in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: The urine appears yellower when hydrated

options.label: B
options.text: The urine appears clearer when dehydrated

options.label: C
options.text: The body's fluid levels are stabilized

title: Why Shakespeare loved iambic pentameter - David T. Freeman and Gregory Taylor

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the most important things in Shakespeare's language?
What is a "foot" in poetry?

options.label: C
options.text: A certain number of stressed and unstressed syllables forming a distinct unit

multiple-choice.question: What type of foot is a dactyl?

options.label: A
options.text: A metrical foot of two syllables with the first stressed and the second unstressed

options.label: B
options.text: A metrical foot of three syllables with the first stressed and the second and third unstressed

options.label: C
options.text: A metrical foot of four syllables with the first and third stressed and the second and fourth unstressed

options.label: D
options.text: A metrical foot of five syllables with the first and third stressed and the second and fourth unstressed

multiple-choice.question: What is iambic pentameter?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of poetic meter with five stressed syllables per line

options.label: B
options.text: A type of poetic meter with five two-syllable iambs per line

options.label: C
options.text: A type of poetic meter with ten stressed syllables per line

options.label: D
options.text: A type of poetic meter with ten two-syllable trochees per line

multiple-choice.question: Why did Shakespeare often use iambic pentameter in his plays?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was easy for his actors to memorize and for the audience to understand

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was a popular poetic meter at the time

options.label: C
options.text: Because it was well-suited to the English language

multiple-choice.question: How does the use of iambic pentameter contribute to the emotional impact of Shakespeare's plays?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a sense of tension and conflict

options.label: B
options.text: It creates a sense of passion and introspection

options.label: C
options.text: It creates a sense of distance and objectivity

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on the emotional impact of the plays

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of using trochees in poetry?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a sense of lightness and playfulness

options.label: B
options.text: It creates a sense of darkness and foreboding

options.label: C
options.text: It creates a sense of neutrality and objectivity

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the tone of the poetry

multiple-choice.question: How does Shakespeare's use of poetic meter contribute to the overall meaning of his plays?

options.label: A
options.text: It adds depth and complexity to the language

options.label: B
options.text: It creates a sense of rhythm and musicality

options.label: C
options.text: It emphasizes certain themes and emotions

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the "iamb" in iambic pentameter?

options.label: A
options.text: It refers to the unstressed syllable in a foot

options.label: B
options.text: It refers to the stressed syllable in a foot

options.label: C
options.text: It refers to the combination of stressed and unstressed syllables in a foot

options.label: D
options.text: It refers to the rhythm of the heart

multiple-choice.question: How does the rhythm of iambic pentameter relate to the human experience?

options.label: A
options.text: It mimics the rhythm of the heart

options.label: B
options.text: It mimics the rhythm of breathing

options.label: C
options.text: It mimics the rhythm of speech

options.label: D
options.text: It has no relation to the human experience

title: Why do buildings fall in earthquakes? - Vicki V. May

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of building collapse during an earthquake?

options.label: A
options.text: The ground beneath the building shaking violently

options.label: C
options.text: The displacement of the foundation and lower levels, sending shock waves through the structure

multiple-choice.question: What factors determine the strength of a building's oscillation during an earthquake?

options.label: C
options.text: Shape of columns and foundation type

multiple-choice.question: Why did many mid-sized buildings (between 6 and 15 stories tall) collapse during the 1985 Mexico City earthquake?

options.label: A
options.text: They were too short and stiff

options.label: B
options.text: They were too tall and flexible

options.label: C
options.text: Their natural frequency matched the frequency of the earthquake's seismic waves, causing resonance

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between a building's mass and its natural frequency?
What is the purpose of base isolation in earthquake-resistant building design?

options.label: C
options.text: To isolate the foundation's displacement from the rest of the building

multiple-choice.question: What type of buildings are more susceptible to damage from low-frequency earthquake motions?

options.label: C
options.text: Buildings with a high natural frequency

options.label: D
options.text: Buildings with a low natural frequency

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of tuned mass damper systems in earthquake-resistant building design?

options.label: C
options.text: To cancel out resonance by oscillating out of phase with the natural frequency

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between a building's stiffness and its natural frequency?
Why do engineers work with geologists and seismologists to predict the frequency of earthquake motions at building sites?

options.label: A
options.text: To determine the building's natural frequency

multiple-choice.question: What is the key factor in determining a building's ability to withstand earthquakes?

title: Why the Arctic is climate change's canary in the coal mine - William Chapman

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the Arctic's sensitivity to climate change?

options.label: B
options.text: The canary in the coal mine

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the Arctic warms, causing some of the snow and ice to melt?

options.label: A
options.text: The ground and ocean underneath absorb less heat

options.label: B
options.text: The ground and ocean underneath absorb more heat

options.label: C
options.text: The ground and ocean underneath reflect more sunlight

options.label: D
options.text: The ground and ocean underneath reflect less sunlight

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of a small drop in temperatures in the Arctic?

options.label: A
options.text: More melting of snow and ice

options.label: B
options.text: More freezing, increasing the amount of reflective snow and ice

options.label: C
options.text: No change in the amount of snow and ice

options.label: D
options.text: A decrease in the amount of reflective snow and ice

multiple-choice.question: How does Arctic sea ice act as a feedback mechanism through insulation?

options.label: A
options.text: By forming a layer on the ocean's surface, allowing heat to escape

options.label: B
options.text: By forming a layer on the ocean's surface, acting as a buffer between the frigid arctic air and the relatively warmer water underneath

options.label: C
options.text: By melting and releasing moisture into the atmosphere

options.label: D
options.text: By freezing and absorbing heat from the atmosphere

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a negative feedback loop in the Arctic?

options.label: A
options.text: Melting ice causing more ice to melt

options.label: B
options.text: Melting ice releasing moisture into the atmosphere, increasing the amount and thickness of clouds

options.label: C
options.text: Freezing ice causing more ice to freeze

options.label: D
options.text: Freezing ice releasing heat into the atmosphere

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of increased moisture and clouds in the Arctic during most of the year?

options.label: A
options.text: Cooling the atmosphere by blocking more sunlight

options.label: B
options.text: Warming the surface by trapping the Earth's heat

options.label: D
options.text: Reducing the amount of clouds present

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of positive feedback loops in the Arctic?

options.label: A
options.text: Encouraging stability by pushing a system towards equilibrium

options.label: B
options.text: Destabilizing the system by enabling larger and larger deviations

options.label: C
options.text: Reducing the impact of climate change

options.label: D
options.text: Increasing the amount of snow and ice

multiple-choice.question: How does the Arctic's sensitivity to climate change affect the rest of the planet?

options.label: A
options.text: By reducing the impact of climate change

options.label: B
options.text: By increasing the temperature differences between the North Pole and the equator

options.label: C
options.text: By reducing the temperature differences between the North Pole and the equator, leading to slower jet stream winds and less linear atmospheric circulation

options.label: D
options.text: By having no effect on the rest of the planet

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential consequence of shifts in weather patterns due to the Arctic's sensitivity to climate change?

options.label: C
options.text: Short-term fluctuations becoming persistent cold snaps, heat waves, droughts, and floods

multiple-choice.question: Why is the Arctic's sensitivity to climate change important to the rest of the planet?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it serves as an early warning alarm for climate change

options.label: B
options.text: Because its feedback loops can affect the rest of the planet in direct and immediate ways

options.label: C
options.text: Because it has no impact on the rest of the planet

options.label: D
options.text: Because it reduces the impact of climate change

title: McDonald's Cup Sizes Around The World

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which an object's velocity increases as it moves closer to a source of gravitational pull?
Which of the following types of energy is associated with the motion of an object?
What is the scientific term for the "building blocks of matter"?
If a force of 10 N is applied to an object, causing it to accelerate at 2 m/s^2, what is the mass of the object?
What is the term for the amount of matter in an object?
A ball is rolled across a frictionless surface. What will happen to its velocity over time?
What is the scientific term for the study of the behavior of objects in motion?
What is the term for the force that opposes motion between two surfaces that are in contact?
A block of ice is floating in a container of water. What will happen to the water level if the block of ice melts?
What is the scientific term for the transfer of energy from one object to another through direct contact?

title: The great conspiracy against Julius Caesar - Kathryn Tempest

multiple-choice.question: Who was the Roman Senator that led the conspiracy against Julius Caesar?
What was the event that led to Julius Caesar's rise to power?

options.label: A
options.text: His victory in the civil war against Pompey the Great

options.label: C
options.text: His distribution of lands to the poor

multiple-choice.question: What was the principle that Rome was founded upon, which was threatened by Julius Caesar's rise to power?

options.label: C
options.text: The principle that no one man should hold too much power

multiple-choice.question: Why did Brutus join the conspiracy against Julius Caesar despite their close relationship?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he was jealous of Caesar's power

options.label: B
options.text: Because he was afraid of Caesar's ambitions

options.label: C
options.text: Because he wanted to avenge his ancestor's death

options.label: D
options.text: Because he was bribed by the other conspirators

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Julius Caesar's assassination?

options.label: A
options.text: The end of the Roman Republic and the rise of the Empire

options.label: B
options.text: The establishment of a new Roman Republic

options.label: C
options.text: The rise of Mark Antony to power

options.label: D
options.text: The defeat of the conspirators and the execution of Brutus

multiple-choice.question: How did the Roman public react to Julius Caesar's assassination?

options.label: A
options.text: They were outraged and demanded justice for the conspirators

options.label: B
options.text: They were divided in their opinions, with some supporting the conspirators and others opposing them

options.label: C
options.text: They were indifferent and did not care about the event

options.label: D
options.text: They were frightened and fled the city

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the power vacuum created by Julius Caesar's assassination?

options.label: A
options.text: The rise of a new Roman Republic

options.label: B
options.text: The establishment of a temporary dictatorship

options.label: D
options.text: The appointment of a new emperor

multiple-choice.question: How did Brutus ultimately die?

options.label: A
options.text: He was executed by the Roman authorities

options.label: B
options.text: He was killed in battle by Mark Antony's forces

multiple-choice.question: What is the legacy of Brutus in history and literature?

options.label: A
options.text: He is universally regarded as a hero and a champion of liberty

options.label: B
options.text: He is universally regarded as a traitor and a villain

options.label: C
options.text: His legacy is divided, with some regarding him as a hero and others as a traitor

options.label: D
options.text: He is largely forgotten and ignored

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the questions raised by the story of Julius Caesar's assassination that are still relevant today?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of loyalty and friendship

options.label: B
options.text: The dangers of ambition and the corrupting influence of power

options.label: C
options.text: The price of liberty and the conflict between personal loyalties and universal ideals

options.label: D
options.text: The role of fate and destiny in shaping human events

title: How do the lungs work? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of breathing in the human body?

options.label: B
options.text: To transport oxygen to the body's cells and clear carbon dioxide

multiple-choice.question: Which system is responsible for controlling the vital functions, including breathing, without conscious thought?
What is the name of the muscle that flattens to create more space for the lungs to expand during inhalation?
What is the term for the tiny air passages that divide from the bronchi in the lungs?
What is the name of the protein in red blood cells that binds to oxygen?
What is the process by which oxygen and carbon dioxide molecules move from an area of high concentration to an area of low concentration?
How often do the lungs inhale and exhale per minute?
What is the approximate volume of air that the lungs inhale and exhale per day?
What happens to the diaphragm during exhalation?
What is the name of the tissue that makes up the spongy interior of the lungs?
